comments.commentBody:
Interesting to see the NYT leave the comments section open far longer than usual for this article, which details mostly very common accounting procedures used by millions of businesses across the country. It's a shameless attempt to please the angry liberals and appease the Bernie Sanders supporters, who are more than happy to pile on their rage about how rich folks are "destroying America".

My small business uses almost all of the "tax avoidance" techniques listed in this article. And you, commenters full of hatred, do you deduct your mortgage interest? How about your deductions for your children? Yep, you sure do. You know why? Because so does everyone else. You are all using "politically motivated tax avoidance schemes". Give me a break.

Great Balzac quote. I'm not a bible reader, but: Matthew 16:26 (KJV)
For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and yet lose his own soul? Or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?
Wall St. (1987)
Gordon Gekko: The point is ladies and gentlemen that greed, for lack of a better word, is good; if you're not inside, you're outside; the most valuable commodity I know of is information; it's all about bucks, kid. The rest is just conversation.
Bud Fox: How much is enough?
Lou Mannheim: Man looks into the abyss, there's nothin' looking back at him. At that moment man finds his character. And that is what keeps him out of the abyss.

12-29-15@10:49 pm est
So the greasy rich should pay less tax than a poor slob because they can pay a team of lawyers and accountants? You're part of the problem.

Well, the vaunted defenders of the celebrated progressive tax code are probably wondering how this could have happened in the first place.
1. This is nothing new. Remember those 90% marginal rates that everyone swore were so high in the 50s and 60s? Deductions and credits at such high rates led directly to the alternate minimum tax as a way to stop "too many" deductions. So much for progressive tax code. That did not work either.
2. The founding fathers understood how corruption would impact government revenues. In fact, they were very worried about the arbitrary takings of the monarchy, forced loans, and "taxes" designed to eliminate wealthy competition. They responded by ensuring that all taxes had to be proportional to ensure levies were uniform on all people. They were so worried about an inequitable tax code that they wrote this into the Constitution.
3. FDR broke this proportional tax base and passed the income tax by focusing on the wealthy. It was never supposed to hit the middle class. It was focused on breaking up the obscene wealth of the Guilded Age. Sure enough, government grew and it now hits the middle class. Even in Europe, the middle class pays the majority of the taxes despite "progressive" claims of superior tax codes.
In the end, we ignored the sage advice of those that experienced arbitrary taxes and confiscation, and we now have a terrible tax system gamed by the very people it was instituted to tax. Time for a flat tax, no deductions.

The father died before his grand daughter suffered the stroke. His wife suffered from dementia. An attorney and bank officer failed to advise the daughters of the existing trusts and wills and compelled the dementia ridden mother to sign papers changing the testamentary documents that created 8 trusts, changed a will and literally defrauded the daughters.
Not joking. The matter is in the courts.

Depressing. There is not any better argument for socialism than the one which has been inadvertently presented in this eye-opener. Bernie Sanders should reprint the entire article in full on every pamphlet he sends.

I am very reluctant to see socialism come as a replacement for capitalism, but the thinking behind these wealthy elitists leaves the rest of America no choice but to steer the ship of state on an entirely new course. Call it revolution if necessary, but it it time to rethink America from the ground up and take whatever action necessary to save the country from itself.

There are many who would take action,but with our over invasive and spying government, it would be really difficult to get a revolution going here. One could not simply put out an email,phone calls or Facebook posts to gather the masses. Homeland Security would have us arrested for sedition. The COINTEL program shut down any thoughts of revolution or radical change in this country back in the 60's and 70's and much more sophisticated means are available now. Maybe everyone in this country should read "A Tale of Two Cities" as a primer on how to start a revolution, though I'd eliminate the guillotine this time.

You are aware that mostly whites "rely on government support" as they are the majority.  What you should have said was more and more low-income Americans will rely on government support and the suicide rate of middle-aged white men will continue to rise.   The middle class is shrinking and the polar caps are melting.

If there is no middle class, 75% of the houses in most major cities will be vacated and GM and Toyota will have no one to sell cars to and most grocery stores will get their income from food stamps.  This is not going to happen.    Obviously, fewer and fewer people will have most of the capital assets in the United States and more and more non-whites will rely on government support, but the middle class will continue to have enough money to own a house, buy a car, buy groceries and sent kids to 1,000's of colleges and technical institutes begging for students, even as they raise list prices.

I think it was Ben Franklin who said "nothing can be said to be certain but death and taxes". Although escaping the certainty of taxes may be a profitable game for the uber-wealthy, they may find death evasion a bit more of a challenge.
No cause they die knowing their families sre going to be financially great while the rest of us worry about bills for everything!!
Read the article.  It notes that flat tax would benefit the mega rich more. Note that it is the mega rich who clamor for it most.
As I get older my appreciation of Maximilien Francois Marie Isidore de Robespierre grows and grows.

I have "Obamacare" and kept my family doctor. I don't know anyone who didn't get to keep their doctor. The only time I hear this nonsense is from people who listen to Rush Limbaugh who don't have Obamacare and don't know anyone who does.

Would have to say at this time the wealthy set up foundations to avoid the estate tax, set up businesses in bermuda to avoid taxes, get their names all over hospitals, museums, sidewalks, Parks( Washington Square Park as an example-Tisch), control Congress, the presidency, and never feel compelled to call for a simple Progressive flat tax that it is time for a new one time tax on the wealthy of 25% of their wealth. Whether they have it in foundations, trusts, estates, we are at war, and the President should issue an order placing this 25% tax on all estates, trusts, and foundations of more then $ 50 million. The system is rotting from within as the wealthy control the politicians that control the social , economic, and political policies that only give them more power. Apple has $ 210 billion in cash and we are at war, and it is time for all of the cash to come home with an executive order. No one really knows the wealth of all our foundations, trusts, and estates, and it is time for a special war tax to help balance or reduce the budget asap.

So what looks like a tuning fork, but adjusts society?  What has tines but is not used for meals?  What gives voice to the ignored and abused throngs without official voice or ear?  What is in a massive treasury keep without a soul?  Outraged yet?

One of the most egregiously misleading statement in this article is these oligarchs have "created" wealth. For the vast majority, who manage other people's money, better descriptions are that they have "concentrated", "skimmed", or "stolen" wealth. This is the same cast of characters that helped to "create" the wealth that vanished in the 2008 crash. People who create and lead companies, or develop new technologies, create wealth. These folks are parasites in that system, parasites that will ultimately destroying their host.

The Wealthy are like magicians. As long as the discussion continues to be about "Income Taxes" their "Wealth" is safe. Higher Income taxes to the Super Rich actually produce greater Wealth. Wealth is a relative thing, and more of everyone's income that is taxed, especially those trying to become wealthy, the wealthy stay relatively richer than everyone else. It is amazing how the American public has been duped into demanding higher income taxes on the "Rich" when they all want to become rich. Higher Income Taxes will prevent most people from becoming rich, and at the same time, keep the people who are already wealthy protected.

The article eludes to one solution, but does not elaborate. While a wealth tax may not seem like a fair tax because if the people worked hard for their wealth, they probably did pay income taxes as their earned their fortune. However, what about the people who did not work hard for their wealth? What about the people who inherit vast sums of money? Would it not be more fair to look at life like the Board game Monopoly? When the game is over, all the money goes back in the box, and the game is put away so the next set of players can enjoy the game. Why can't we develop a tax system that mirrors this simple Board game? The tax system could be as simple as when you die, you are free to either give your money away to a qualified charity, or give it to the government. For liberals, this would be the ultimate Progressive Tax.
We had two miraculous elections in Canada this year - the defeat of the Conservatives in Alberta (provincially), and federally.  It's time for a revolution in U.S. politics too.
Your first sentence can be read a couple of different ways with very different meanings
America , as I hoped, is over. It has been reformatted.
What? Rich people rig the tax system? Ridiculous! Next, you'll tell me politicians can buy influence.

Actually it is the point. Most Americans and 95% of the world's population could live their entire lives with one year of after tax 200k income. But I think your real aim in broadcasting this message was quite simple: congratulations!

Like many incidents of violence there was an act of aggression that was responded to... Simpley put, if molitor had not punched mixin this incident would never have happened... When a person is attacted  the adrenalin starts flowing  and the response  can be devastating... Even though  it was a woman who started the confrontation the pc's automatically blame the male...the politically correct  elitists are the reason for the rise of Donald trump...
Ah yes, the classic "adrenalin" defense.  Where Peter lives, once that 'adrenalin' starts flowing all bets are off.  She's lucky to have survived at all.  Glad I don't live there.
The point is she was no shrinking violet. Why was she hitting him at all? Yes, he should have walked away, but both seem to be having trouble.

Not only was the aggressor the woman, but she was also a convicted drug felon. Imagine for a moment if we turned the story around, and they were both men, and a young black drug felon pushed and then slapped a white honors student. Would we be up in arrms if he clocked him? What if the instigator was a man, and after pushing and slapping a woman, she broke his face with a punch? Surely the justice system shouldn't turn on the gender of the combatants.

If the NYT wants to write about the hypocrisy in the NFL, about double standards for athletes, or about athletes hitting their significant others ( I point to Hope Solo as an example of a female batterer) there are plenty of examples out there. I encourage you to take these hypocrites to task. But do a little journalistic legwork. Dont bend the facts to suit your pre existing

Ms Molitor was arrested in April 2013 for possession of and possible intent to sell drugs and possession of a controlled drug class III and possession of a false ID. She plead no contest and the sentence was 1 year deferred with a substance abuse eval and community service. Her Judge in Then in December 2013, she was arrested again on 1 count of possession of a controlled drug, 1 count of possession of drug paraphernalia, 1 count of transporting an open container of alcohol, 1 count of minor in possession of intoxicating beverage. Those charges are still pending.
Giants have more problems than an aging successful coach and an experienced quarterback. I just can't put my finger on it

The team is low on talent.  That is the fault of the GM.  The team does not play up to the level of its talent.  That is the fault of the coach.  Four bad seasons.  Time to clean house and start again.

As much as I'd like to lay the blame at Coughlin's feet - yeah, some of his calls during the season turned out to be bone-headed decisions - you need to take into account the much bigger picture. To wit:

1) Injuries destroyed this team. What a horrid streak of bad luck. And of course, the JPP fiasco - the team's best defensive lineman blows off part of his hand after screwing around with firecrackers? Who could predict that?

2) You're only as good as the talent you're given. I don't think I'm shocking anybody when I say that this cohort of Giants just might be the dumbest assembly of jocks to ever suit up in our beloved blue. These guys are serious knuckleheads. Time and again, they make mistakes on the field. And then there are the unnecessary roughness calls, which have killed us. That's because too many of our guys are just dumb and don't have minimum self control. It's a far, far cry from the days when we had the likes of the greats, like Harry Carson, Lawrence Taylor, Gary Reasons and Carl Banks at linebacker or Jim Burt and Leonard Marshall on the line. Etc. etc. Those players were every bit as physical as the current Giants - but they were light years smarter. It's a question of IQ; when it comes to smarts, we just have a dumb team.

The GM: Jerry Reece has been mediocre, at best. Go through his draft picks and with the exception of Beckham - which was lucky - he's had more stinkers than keepers. Fire him before Coughlin.
